awd_titl_txt: Midisuperspace Laboratories for the Dynamics of Loop Quantum Gravity
awd_abstract_narration:
The study of how black holes evaporate is perhaps the most important outstanding problem in theoretical physics today. It requires that we understand the behavior of  two of the pillars of modern physics, gravity and quantum field theory, in their most extreme regimes. Understanding how physical theories fit together in challenging regimes has in the past led to insights of spectacular consequences. An example of this could be Maxwell's understanding of how electricity and magnetism fit together led to the discovery of radio waves, with the ensuing transformational changes they induced in our society. A second very important objective of this type of work is the formation of human resources of very high quality. Physicists trained in these disciplines have proved valuable in industry and in finance.

This award supports studies of loop quantum gravity in spherically symmetric contexts with the ultimate goal of understanding black hole evaporation. This includes work on the back-reaction of quantum fields living on spherically symmetric quantum space-times. The discreteness of the quantum space-time naturally regularizes the infinities of quantum field theory. To study the back reaction will require quantum space-times more realistic than the ones considered so far, including dynamical evolution. The work will attempt to find the quantum space-time of a collapsing shell and compute the Hawking radiation produced and eventually the back reaction of fields living on it. In addition to this, the PI's group will study the structure of the quantum space-times, in particular their singularity structure in the case of extremal and super extremal charged black holes and the Cauchy horizons that appear in the solutions. Finally,  the semiclassical collapse of a scalar field will be studied to understand how quantum effects change the universality and scaling first discovered by Choptuik.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The two most successful theories of physics are Einstein's general relativity and quantum mechanics. The first provides the most accurate description of gravity at present. The second offeres an excellent description of the microscopic world, at the atomic and subatomic level. However, both theories are separate and rely on different frameworks in terms of ideas and math. We do not understand at present how to make them work together. There are various proposals, but none is considered complete or consistent. Further complicating the situation is that it is difficult to find situations where both theories are relevant. Gravity is an interaction that domiates at the macro level, being important for astronomy and large objects. Quantum mechanics is not needed to describe the macro world, it only is crucial when one goes at the atomic or subatomic level. 

There are a few situations we can imagine where both theories should be needed simultaneously to describe nature: the Big Bang and black holes. The first corresponds to the origin of our universe, when all that composes it was concentrated in a very small region that would later expand to give rise to the universe we observe today. Black holes are the remnants left at the end of the life of certain stars. They are objects so dense that nothing can escape their gravitational attraction, not even light. At the Big Bang and the interior of black holes gravity is intense and things are compressed into small volumes, making both general relativity and quantum mechanics necessary. So those two situations attract the most interest of researchers working on building theories of quantum gravity, the sought after theory that would put general relativity and quantum mechanics in a common framework.

Due to the complexity of these situations, the approach taken by many researchers, including this proposal, is to study models where one makes drastic simplifications yet attempts to capture the essence of what is studied. 

In our studies we have found that certain proposals for quantum gravity imply that the waves in the gravitational field (gravitational waves) that black holes produce when they interact, and that have been detected on Earth by the NSF-funded LIGO detectors, may have subtle imprints that depend on the proposal considered. This could help determine if they are viable or not by checking if they conflict with the observations. 

We have also found that proposals for the Big Bang leave signatures on the cosmic microwave background radiation, microwaves that arrive to us from the Big Bang and are detected by radiotelescopes both on Earth and in satellites in space, and could also be used to rule out some proposals for quantum gravity. 

We also studied the formation of very small black holes. These are not the endpoints of the life of stars but are conjectured to form early in the universe due to fluctuations. 

The proposal engaged young postdoctoral researchers and graduate students and the PI also carries out a vigorous online outreach program through the loop quantum gravity portal.
